abstract.text: Make your apps accessible to everyone who uses Apple devices.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Accessibility features help a wide range of people interact with their devices.
By creating your app with accessibility in mind, you make it possible for everyone
Whether you’re developing a new app, or updating an existing one, consider the needs
of all the people who might use your app.
For many, accessibility is a necessity.
For example, closed captions can be necessary for someone who is deaf or hard of hearing,
but also useful for someone watching a video in a noisy environment.
Learn more about how to support different types of accessibility needs in your app using Apple’s wide range of accessibility APIs.
Explore how sample apps leverage accessible design principles and accessibility APIs to create a great user experience for everyone.
People can personalize their devices by choosing the accessibility features and
assistive technologies that give them the best user experience.
Make sure your app provides a great experience for people who use assistive technologies by testing your app with them.

accessibility-card-cognitive.png.alt: An illustration that shows a person standing and looking at an Apple Watch on their left wrist.

accessibility-card-hearing.png.alt: An illustration that shows a person wearing a hearing aid and a camping backpack. The person is walking and using an iPhone.

accessibility-card-mobility.png.alt: An illustration that shows a person in a wheelchair using a MacBook in their lap.

accessibility-card-speech.png.alt: An illustration that shows a person in an electric wheelchair sitting at a desk and using speech synthesis features on a Mac.

accessibility-card-vision.png.alt: An illustration that shows a person with low vision walking with the assistance of a guide dog while using an iPhone and AirPods.

abstract.text: Make your apps accessible to everyone who uses Apple devices.
A token object that represents an override session held by your app.
Options indicating which Accessibility features will be turned on or off when an override session is held by your app.

A manager class to begin and end accessibility feature override sessions. Multiple override sessions are reconciled by combining the requests, preferring feature enablement. Ending all sessions restores the prior state of Accessibility feature enablement. Your app must be entitled with com.apple.developer.accessibility.merchant-api-control.
Browse API in the Accessibility framework.
Make your apps accessible to everyone who uses visionOS.
Reveal how your app represents itself to people using accessibility features.
Improve navigation in your app by using keyboard shortcuts and accessibility containers.
A mode that tailors the iOS and iPadOS experience for people with cognitive disabilities.
Make sure your app provides a great experience for people who use assistive technologies.
A person may have difficulty remembering a sequence of steps, or they
may find an overly complex user interface difficult to process and manage.
Make improvements to your app’s interaction model to support assistive technologies such as VoiceOver.
Support advancements in SwiftUI accessibility to make your app accessible to everyone.

doc://com.apple.Accessibility/documentat.title: Enhancing the accessibility of your SwiftUI app

abstract.text: A person may be deaf, have partial hearing loss, or have difficulty hearing
sounds within a certain range.
Make your app more accessible to users with disabilities by adding accessibility features.
A person with reduced mobility may have difficulty holding a device
or tapping the interface.
Test your app with accessibility settings and assistive technologies to discover and address accessibility issues.

doc://com.apple.Accessibility/documentat.title: Performing accessibility testing for your app

abstract.text: A person may have a speech disability or prefer to connect without using their voice.
An interface for navigating a device with a variety of adaptive switch hardware, wireless game controllers, or sounds such as a click or a pop.
A person may be blind or color blind, or have a vision challenge that
makes focusing difficult.
An interface for navigating a device using voice commands to tap, swipe, type, and more.
A gesture-based screen reader that provides an auditory description of the content onscreen.
Design for large text sizes by modifying the user interface.
Simulate a conversation using speech synthesis.
Navigate to the end of a dark maze using VoiceOver as your guide.
Play a card-matching game using Switch Control.

doc://com.apple.Accessibility/documentat.title: WWDC22 Challenge: Learn Switch Control through gaming

abstract.text: Accessible user interfaces empower everyone to have a great experience with your app or game.
Make your AppKit apps accessible to everyone who uses macOS.
Make your SwiftUI apps accessible to everyone, including people with disabilities.
Make your UIKit apps accessible to everyone who uses iOS and tvOS.
Learn about important changes to Accessibility.
Make your app accessible to everyone by applying accessibility modifiers to your SwiftUI views.
Leverage SwiftUI to build an immersive media experience in a multiplatform app.
Leverage a Full Space to create a fun game using ARKit.

Learn how Assistive Access can help people with cognitive disabilities more easily use iPhone and iPad. Discover the design principles that guide Assistive Access and find out how the system experience adapts to lighten cognitive load. We’ll show you how Assistive Access works and what you can do to support this experience in your app.

Bring the latest advancements in Speech Synthesis to your apps. Learn how you can integrate your custom speech synthesizer and voices into iOS and macOS. We’ll show you how SSML is used to generate expressive speech synthesis, and explore how Personal Voice can enable your augmentative and assistive communication app to speak on a person’s behalf in an authentic way.

doc://com.apple.documentation/videos/pla.title: Extend Speech Synthesis with personal and custom voices

abstract.text: Learn how you can make spatial computing apps that work well for everyone. Like all Apple platforms, visionOS is designed for accessibility: We’ll share how we’ve reimagined assistive technologies like VoiceOver and Pointer Control and designed features like Dwell Control to help people interact in the way that works best for them. Learn best practices for vision, motor, cognitive, and hearing accessibility and help everyone enjoy immersive experiences for visionOS.

Discover how you can test your app for accessibility with every build. Learn how to perform automated audits for accessibility using XCTest and find out how to interpret the results. We’ll also share enhancements to the accessibility API that can help you improve UI test coverage.

doc://com.apple.documentation/videos/pla.title: Perform accessibility audits for your app

abstract.text: Discover how advancements in UI frameworks make it easier to build rich, accessible experiences. Find out how technologies like VoiceOver can better interact with your app’s interface through accessibility traits and actions. We’ll share the latest updates to SwiftUI that help you refine your accessibility experience and show you how to keep accessibility information up-to-date in your UIKit apps.

doc://com.apple.documentation/videos/pla.title: Build accessible apps with SwiftUI and UIKit

abstract.text: Learn how to design engaging immersive experiences for visionOS that respect the limitations of human vision and motion perception. We’ll show you how you can use depth cues, contrast, focus, and motion to keep people comfortable as they enjoy your apps and games.

doc://com.apple.documentation/videos/pla.title: Design considerations for vision and motion
